wikipedia_page.main: Lieutenant Arthur Frederick Britton  (2 October 1888 – 19 February 1919) was a World War I flying ace credited with six aerial victories.

link_mentions.page: List of World War I aces credited with 6 victories

response: He was transferred to No. 57 Squadron RFC in 1917 to fly the Airco DH.4 two-seater day bomber. Paired with observer/gunner Lieutenant Arthur Britton, Minôt gained his first aerial victories on 3 July 1917, accounting for two Albatros D.Vs over Zonnebeke, one driven down out of control and the other shot down flames, killing Albert Dossenbach. On 7 July, with AM1 Goffe as his observer, he drove down another D.V north-east of Ypres. Britton had returned as his observer on 27 July when they drove down three D.Vs over Houthulst. As a result of this action, and that of 7 July, Minôt would be awarded the Military Cross, while Britton received the Croix de guerre.
